column4: how can I change to a directory on terminal mounted with smb://
how can I change directory on terminal for a network place? it is mounted on smb://<mynetwork>
it can't be "mounted" to smb://anything, because that's not a mountpoint
is there any way I can access the files of my network hdd using terminal?
yes, but you have to actually mount it. the link i gave you should have instructions for that. anyway short version, "sudo mount //servername/sharename /mnt/whatever -o username=blah"
depends what you mean by "damaging your system". besides, why would you want to do that?
the problem is that I need to update my system and when I did "df" whis is what I got http://pastebin.ubuntu.com/154108/
/tmp is only full because your main drive is full to begin with.
it shows me that I have 3gb of free space. I dont get it
you have a 10gb root partition, and it's full
thanks :), now, how can I get rid of the last few kernel images?
